author: timhc22
content: <@!221704135714668556>, <@!84772078993039360>, do you have any knowledge of how projects like lazy (the NFT displaying site) and Opensea are able to provide a list of NFTs in one's wallet? I guess they would have a (centralised) caching system constantly monitoring the blockchain and creating a new data set right?

author: steelyeyedspaceman
content: <@597792256837156971> they probably have a local DB that stores contract addresses as people upload the contract address. Once you have the address you can get the url that links to the NFT offchain metadata via web3. Opensea just hosts all their NFT metadata themselves though, so it makes it easy to bring up and display. Although it goes against the spirit of decentralization

author: steelyeyedspaceman
content: I use IPFS for my NFTs, cuz decentralized is fun. Although I'll admit, even IPFS isnt decentralized unless someone else pins your data

author: timhc22
content: Yea but, if I want to see all the nfts  (or tokens) in someone's wallet, before I can even get the meta data, I have to scan every contract on ethereum for every appearance of my wallet address, and then find the current 'state' of what I own for each one (at least if I understand correctly)

author: timhc22
content: So.. (and I hope this is an OK place for this conversation, <@301186049323958275> please let me know if it isn't), so every time anything new is minted, it would need to be scanned and constantly checking for the appearance of my interacting with it
